This question has been answered differently throughout history. Aristotle argued that the different elements had their "natural place" which they tended to. Thus a rock, in which the "element" earth prevailed, fell because the natural place of that element is the bottom. Instead, fire had its natural place at the top, and so something like smoke tended to rise. This idea of "natural places" may seem naive to us today, but it prevailed for centuries. But better than showing a condescending attitude to such "naive" theories would be to understand that human beings are prone to accept as natural the theories prevalent in our time. To put it clearly, are we sure that our current understanding of gravity is the right one? Well, we must admit something, Newton's idea that between two bodies there is an attraction proportional to their mass and inversely proportional to the square of the distance that separates them was, undoubtedly, the most important step in many centuries. Among other things because it allowed us to understand the reason for the elliptical orbits of the planets and, above all, to make precise calculations based on only two important variables: the mass and the distance that separates the bodies under consideration. Now, recognizing the practical superiority of Newton's model over Aristotle's, the question remains why does one object attract and, at the same time, is attracted by another? It seemed that we had left behind the Aristotelian idea of natural place, but in the end, had we? Newton, perhaps annoyed by the question of the origin of that attraction, wrote his famous phrase: hypotheses non fingo, "I feign no hypotheses" or, to put it another way: I do not know and I prefer not to propose hypotheses. I want to say with this that "the gist", the crux of the matter continued unexplained, in spite of the giant step that the Newtonian theory represented. And we all know how this story continues: with Einstein's general theory of relativity. Leaving aside the practical advantages of Einstein's theory, for instance, to be able to explain phenomena like the anomaly of the mercury orbit, I would like to focus on another point. Einstein, unlike Aristotle and Newton, was the first to propose that bodies, their mass in fact, provoked "something" in their surroundings and that this "something" was related to their attractive capacity. I want to emphasize the change of conception, which breaks decisively with the Newtonian idea that the gravitational interaction is something that happens between the bodies directly, an attraction in which the space is only a sort of passive setting. In that sense, Einstein's theory is a real paradigm shift, a really different way of conceiving gravity that, from now on, necessarily includes the characteristics of the space in which those bodies move. End of the story? Nothing like that! The basic question remains unanswered! If, on the one hand, Newton could not answer for the origin of that mysterious attractive power that bodies seem to possess, Einstein never answered the following question: why does the mass of a body produce the bending of space-time? As we see, it seems that the ultimate answer about the origin of gravity always doesn't escape, like sand between our fingers. And to make matters worse, we now know an important fact that Einstein did not know (let alone Newton): the universe is expanding at an accelerated rate. This disconcerting fact further complicates the scenario. Is there perhaps a kind of negative gravity affecting the universe on a large scale? Explaining this fact is a new challenge, but, I wonder, is it not an opportunity? An opportunity for what? you may ask. An opportunity to explain, for the first time, the ultimate origin of that force we call gravity! How so? Let's see, Einstein says that mass produces a curvature in spacetime but also, with his "strong" equivalence principle that there seems to be a close relationship between what happens to a body in a gravitational field and what happens to that same body when it is subjected to an acceleration. And now we learn that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate! These facts seem unrelated, but they could give us the explanation we are looking for! As I propose in: Enrique Casanovas's answer to What could be the origin of gravity? I think the origin of gravity is explained by this accelerating expansion. But if you read my answer, you will see that I am not exactly talking about the expansion discovered in 1998, which is a 3D expansion. I think it is logical to assume the following: since Minkowski we know that our universe is 4D and therefore I think it is logical to assume that this 3D expansion is only the visible aspect of a 4D expansion. And that would be, finally, the answer. Why do bodies bend spacetime? Because of the inertial resistance to an impulse that accelerates them in that extra direction, the time direction!
